title: What did the classic movie “Lawrence of Arabia” get wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: Too many things — but it’s understandable. The whole presentation of the movie Lawrence of Arabia (1962) was intended to be a dramatisation by director David Lean. If memory serves, the movie was said to have 200 speaking characters — and only eight were non-fictional historical figures. The backdrop political events were correct in generic details, but virtually everything else was ficitonalised and largely inaccurate. Peter O’Toole looked nothing like T.E. Lawrence, and neither did most of the other actors to their real-life characters. If David Lean had intended anything in the movie, it would seem he intended to merely give a “flavour’ of the situation of Lawrence the man and his times. My own feeling is there’s nothing to be disappointed about it. The movie was clearly designed to be a nice Hollywood epic drama using a real historical backdrop and character. It’s a movie. It’s not an actual documentary — indeed, not even a dramatised documentary. Thanks for the A2A.

The movie was very much a dramatization. However the biggest thing left out, and what troubled Lawrence for much of his life, was both his own private homosexuality and his rape in custody. In the closed down mores of the era Lawrence was really messed up to equate his own sexuality and the forced rape he endured.
